answer: Alex Rogachevsky, Lifetime programmer, startup CTOAnswered 4 years ago · Author has 636 answers and 4.3M answer viewsWhat is the best career advice for a software developer to earn a higher salary? Alex Rogachevsky Solve a problem. A business one - that created the need for the software you are developing. Software is such a complex product (like cars and houses), it requires a team of engineers. Employers pigeonhole developers into little specializations. You can happily stay a sniper, machine gunner, or radio operator in your squad arrangement. You can even go to the officer’s academy (business school) to be promoted through official channels. But you need to try it first: comprehending the whole battle and rising above the specialist rank. At least in your mind. You don’t have to write the entire system’s code to do that. Just look at the big picture, identify problems not directly related to you, raise them, and help your teammates to solve them. Solve some yourself - something outside your special Continue Reading

answer: Yes, it does. In the recent past, several Hollywood studios and companies from the west have started investing in India. And Indian VFX studios, too, are flourishing with each passing year. A lot of people find it hard to believe, but the visual effects for some of the biggest blockbusters (300: Rise of an Empire, Godzilla, Maleficent, The Hunger Games, Jupiter Ascending and Pixels) were in fact done here in India. Since it is a market that is known to churn out high-quality VFX work in quick time, India has become the outsourcing hub when it comes to visual effects work for films, television shows, web series and other projects. answer: Relax! You are experiencing something which is very common. Most people won’t discuss about this, because they think it is ‘unethical’ to talk about. Later they choose a career which eventually kill their will to do anything. Never do that! Atleast, you are considering to choose a career. I really appreciate that! So, now that you have asked this question, I guess you might already have something in your mind as a career option, if not, then its fine. Just ask yourself this question, “What do I like to do?”. Your answer might be one of these, if not, then mention in the comment. CookingPlaying a music instrumentRiding motorcycleSportsMaking videosPhotographyPlaying gamesComedyMagicImpressions of celebritiesSinging Ever heard of PewDiePie ? If you haven't, because of some weird reason, then be sure to check him out. He is the most subscribed Youtuber, and made his career just by playing games. Believe me, there are so many successful people who made their career out of things you cannot imagine. So, choose a career based on something you’re really good at and like doing it. But, always remember the most important thing is, ‘you will have to work really hard to achieve success and be the best’. All the best and have a great life ahead! Follow me for more career related posts. Be sure to check out CybrHome - Explore The Internet for more career suggestions and options.

answer: No, it is not ludicrous. I started when I was 10 years older than you. However, you must evaluate the time you have available carefully, as you likely have other obligations and responsibilities at this point in life, such as family and work. Getting started is one thing, seeing things through to an intermediate level is another. There are many excellent ways to start, Learn to code and help nonprofits (freecodecamp dot com) is a good place to start, as is any of the online tutorials available at W3 Schools, codecademy, Khan Academy’s introduction to programming tutorials, Learn TreeHouse, and CodeSchool. answer: The absolute best way is to join the us air force. If you can, make sure you get an afsc (air force job) that has to do with computers and/or intelligence because it will just boost your experience. Some examples include:  Client Systems (3D1X1) Operations Intelligence Specialist (1N0X1) Network Intelligence Analyst Specialist (1N4X1) Cyber Surety (3D0X3) Cyber Systems Operations (3D0X2) Computer Systems Programming (3C0X2) Cyber Transport (3D1X2) Geospatial Intelligence (1N1X1)  While you are in your 4 or 6 year enlistment, work on your bachelors degree in something like Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, or Computer Engineering. Many accredited schools offer these degrees online. answer: It depends on how you take the upcoming opportunities. If you love coding - you will be more than satisfied. Unlike other companies, projects are very challenging ( be it development from scratch or maintenance). You have to work hard and spend your whole day coding. Every single person in a project plays a different role. So you have to work on a module alone and you will learn innumerous things in this process. Moreover, you will not be on bench for much time. Once you get released from any project, many upcoming projects await you. You will be recognised if you have talent in you. You will love everything here (project, work environment, people). At the end what matters is your hardwork and dedication. All the best for your career ! :)
